article:
The 'bar' is a non-SI unit of pressure, defined by the IUPAC as exactly equal to
100,000 Pa. It is about equal to the atmospheric pressure on Earth at
sea level, and since 1982 the IUPAC has recommended that the standard for
atmospheric pressure should be harmonized to 100,000 Pa = 1 bar â
750.0616827 Torr. The same definition is used in the compressor
and the pneumatic tool industries (ISO 2787).

The bar and the millibar were introduced by the British meteorologist William
Napier Shaw in 1909, while he was the director of the Meteorological Office in
London. [http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/Cambridge/entries/061/Sir-William-
Napier-Shaw.html Sir William Napier Shaw]

Units derived from the bar are the 'megabar' (symbol: 'Mbar'), 'kilobar'
(symbol: 'kbar'), 'decibar' (symbol: 'dbar'), 'centibar' (symbol: 'cbar'), and
'millibar' (symbol: 'mbar' or 'mb'). They are not SI or cgs units, but they are
accepted for use with the SI. . The bar is legally recognized in
countries of the European Union. British Standard BS 350:2004
Conversion Factors for Units

The bar unit is officially deprecated International Astronomical Union Style
Manual. Comm. 5 in IAU Transactions XXB, 1989, Table 6 and usage is
strongly discouraged. NIST Special Publication 1038, Sec. 4.3.2 NIST Special
Publication 811, 2008 edition, Sec. 5.2

'Bar(g)' is a unit of gauge pressure, i.e., pressure in bars above ambient or
atmospheric pressure; see absolute pressure and gauge pressure below.
